stream_context.summary: Kaze Emanuar works on UV mapping and texturing 'Course 13', a large ice level for 'Return to Yoshi's Island'. Key topics include a major performance breakthrough involving the N64's RSP, his design philosophy of invoking emotion, the collaborative workflow with artist Biobak, and the personal financial pressures driving his YouTube content strategy.

development_findings.summary: A major technical breakthrough was the discovery that the N64's RSP, not memory traffic, is the primary performance bottleneck when a game is well-optimized, a finding enabled by the new FBDX3 microcode.
development_findings.quote: we were wrong about memory traffic being so important. And instead it's RSP because now with X3, we found out that RSP is actually the limiting factor.

development_findings.summary: The team is running out of collision triangle memory in Course 13, a temporary issue that will be resolved once a proper collision map is implemented for the level.
A lighting bug exists where ambient light disappears near additional light sources on the X2 microcode used in emulation, but it works correctly on the FBDX3 microcode running on hardware.
A demo featuring only Course 1 is planned to allow players to experience the new camera and character controls.
The level design for Course 13 is intentionally labyrinthine, featuring secret pipes and multiple pathways to encourage exploration and provide different perspectives on the level.
The outside area of Course 13 will feature an 8 Red Coins mission and a hidden entrance to an 8-bit section.

context_findings.summary: Kaze feels financial pressure due to having a new child, motivating him to create more YouTube videos, though he worries this might compromise his content's integrity.
context_findings.quote: now that I have a child, I need to make more money. So that means a lot more YouTube content. But it also means I might have to sell out a little bit, unfortunately.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a cynical view of the YouTube landscape, joking at length about manufacturing drama for views, which he sees as the dominant trend on the platform.
context_findings.quote: if you ever look at YouTube, all of YouTube right now is just this person's a pedophile, this person's a groomer. That is what's going well on YouTube. You just have to invent a pedophile to expose him.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's design philosophy prioritizes the emotional impact on the player over pure aesthetics, as demonstrated by his approach to designing the 'cold and mysterious' ice level.
context_findings.quote: When I'm doing visuals, I don't really think about it in terms of like pleasure to look at. That's like secondary to me. For me, I think about it in first line about like emotions I want to invoke in the player.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that to truly learn programming, one should start with a low-level language like MIPS Assembly to build a strong fundamental understanding before moving to higher-level languages.
context_findings.quote: The correct way, according to me, if you really, really want to get into programming, is to learn with MIPS Assembly.

context_findings.summary: Kaze notes that he receives polarized feedback on his games' difficulty, with some players finding them too easy and others, like streamer Simpleflips, struggling with simple tasks, leading to a perception of 'typical Kaze tier difficulty'.
Kaze mentions he has multiple online jobs and recently moved from Germany to Canada, which he considers an improvement.

biobak.summary: Kaze's texturing and visual work on levels serves as a placeholder or 'suggestion' for Biobak, who is responsible for the final artistic polish and implementation.
biobak.quote: I have resigned myself to like knowing that whatever I do is just kind of like a suggestion for Biobak and he's gonna make it look a lot better.

biobak.summary: Kaze expresses confidence that Biobak understands the intended feeling and emotional direction for the levels, indicating a strong, non-verbal alignment in their collaborative process.
biobak.quote: So far we never ran into an issue with that. And you know what the feeling is, you are here in the streams, I imagine you know exactly what I'm looking for.

zeina.summary: Zeina is creating assets for the outside area of Course 13.
A brief personal anecdote reveals that Zeina, Kaze's spouse, also cuts his hair, highlighting the blend of their personal and professional lives.
zeina.quote: I'm not paying for a haircut. I'm making Zeina do it. I don't care how stupid I look.

key_stories.title: The RSP Bottleneck Discovery
key_stories.summary: The team integrated a new microcode, FBDX3, which led to the surprising discovery that the true performance bottleneck was the RSP, not memory traffic as commonly believed. This insight changed their entire approach to optimization and represents a key technical breakthrough for the project.
key_stories.challenge: The N64 development community widely believed memory traffic and RDP fillrate were the primary performance bottlenecks, and the team was seeking further performance gains.
key_stories.process: After implementing Sauraen's new FBDX3 microcode, Kaze noticed that despite significant framerate improvements, the performance counter still indicated an RSP bottleneck. This proved that with memory traffic already optimized, the RSP became the new limiting factor.
key_stories.outcome: The team has shifted their optimization focus to the RSP, unlocking new performance potential. This represents a significant technical learning that challenges common wisdom in the N64 modding scene, which Kaze plans to share publicly.
key_stories.key_quote: We found out that RSP is actually the limiting factor. Now, if you actually optimize your game well.

key_stories.title: The Placeholder Art Philosophy
key_stories.summary: When struggling with the art for a new level, Kaze reframes his work as a 'suggestion' for the team's artist, Biobak. This story reveals their collaborative workflow, built on trust and specialization, where Kaze establishes the emotional and functional foundation and Biobak provides the final visual polish.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze needs to create the visual identity for a level but struggles with his own artistic execution, calling his attempts 'terrible' and 'disgusting'.
key_stories.process: While UV mapping and texturing Course 13, Kaze focuses on his primary goal: invoking a 'cold and mysterious' emotion. He accepts that his visual work is a functional and emotional blueprint rather than a final product.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze proceeds by creating placeholder art that establishes the mood and function of the level, trusting Biobak to handle the final artistic implementation. This workflow allows development to move forward without being blocked by individual skill gaps.
key_stories.key_quote: Really at this point I have resigned myself to like knowing that whatever I do is just kind of like a suggestion for Biobak and he's gonna make it look a lot better.

key_stories.title: The Pressure to Sell Out
key_stories.summary: Driven by the financial needs of his growing family, Kaze discusses the pressure to increase his YouTube output. He candidly voices his fear of having to 'sell out' and jokes about manufacturing drama for views, revealing a tension between his creative passions and the realities of being an online creator.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze needs to increase his income to support his new family, creating pressure to generate more revenue from his YouTube channel.
key_stories.process: Kaze outlines a schedule of legitimate, content-rich videos about his development work. He then contrasts this with a cynical, detailed monologue about creating a fake controversy for views, illustrating his understanding of what drives engagement on the platform.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze plans to significantly increase his video output. While his elaborate plan to manufacture drama is a joke, it reveals his awareness of YouTube trends and the internal conflict between creative authenticity and the financial pressures of being a full-time creator.
key_stories.key_quote: now that I have a child, I need to make more money... it also means I might have to sell out a little bit, unfortunately.

open_questions.context: Kaze stated his visual work is a 'suggestion' for Biobak, who creates the final art. He seems to focus on establishing the level's emotional tone and trusting Biobak to understand it.
questions: Can you walk us through the handover process from your placeholder level to Biobak's final art? What does that collaboration look like?
Biobak, how much creative freedom do you have to interpret or even change the initial mood Kaze establishes?
Has there ever been a time your artistic vision differed significantly from Kaze's initial 'suggestion,' and how did you resolve it?

open_questions.context: Kaze discovered that the RSP, not memory traffic, is the new performance bottleneck after implementing the FBDX3 microcode. This contradicts common knowledge in the N64 modding community.
questions: What was the 'aha' moment like when you realized the bottleneck had shifted from the RDP to the RSP?
How does this discovery change what's possible for the project? Are there ideas you previously dismissed that are now feasible?
What has the reaction been from other N64 developers to this finding?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that his spouse, Zeina, is creating assets for the outside area of Course 13.
questions: Zeina, what is your creative process for creating assets that fit within the world Kaze is building?
Is asset creation your primary role, or are you also involved in the game design and layout of the areas you work on?
How do you two manage the professional and personal aspects of collaborating so closely on a creative project?

open_questions.topic: Balancing creative integrity with financial pressure
open_questions.context: Kaze spoke candidly about needing to make more money due to his new child, and a fear of having to 'sell out' on YouTube.
questions: You joked about manufacturing drama, but what does 'selling out' mean to you in a serious sense? What is a line you wouldn't cross for views or money?
How do you balance making videos on niche, technical topics you're passionate about versus content that might perform better with the YouTube algorithm?
Does the pressure to create more content ever conflict with the development timeline or creative focus for RTYI?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned he is 'not 100% happy' with a boss fight and had to cut a 'dodging the stars' phase because he couldn't get it to work well.
questions: You mentioned you're not satisfied with one of the boss fights. Can you elaborate on what isn't working for you from a design perspective?
What was the original concept for the 'dodging the stars' phase, and what were the specific challenges that led you to cut it?
What are your plans to improve the boss fight to get it to a state you're happy with?
